Comment: Because they're weak.    I just turned 40 and when I was young, we used to casually use slurs to describe anyone who deviated from the heteronormative structure.   It is intellectually dishonest to say that we didn't mean it cruelly. The harm is inherent. It was more a question of exposure to different ways of being human and the slow creep of social norms towards acceptance.   Easy to describe someone as a f or a t. Hard to know someone that the label could be applied to and choose to hurt the real person in front of you.   I am ashamed of how I used to behave. That means in 30 more years, I will probably be ashamed of who I am right now. If we are lucky, we will find new ways to be kind and inclusive and welcome the deviations and that means I will look at how I behave now with horror.   That's a good thing. It means we are evolving and growing over time. I can allow myself to be confronted. I can make an effort to learn, apologize and correct as we continue to change. It is both uncomfortable and necessary.    Transgender people have always been here, but they feel new. New means change. Change creates an obligation to evolve and these bitter, brittle people are committed to stagnating and becoming irrelevant. They lack the courage to accept the part they play in what hurts them and so they blame you.
Author: eaudetrash
